question: Given A = 4i + 6j and B = 2i + 3j. Which of the following is correct?
question_latex: Given $\vec{A}=4\hat{i}+6\hat{j}$ and $\vec{B}=2\hat{i}+3\hat{j}$. Which of the following is correct?
options: D. A and B are anti-parallel
solution:
$\vec{A}\times\vec{B}=(4\hat{i}+6\hat{j})\times(2\hat{i}+3\hat{j}) = 12(\hat{i}\times\hat{j})+12(\hat{j}\times\hat{i})=12(\hat{i}\times\hat{j})-12(\hat{i}\times\hat{j})=0$. 
 Again, $\vec{A}\cdot\vec{B}=(4\hat{i}+6\hat{j})\cdot(2\hat{j}+3\hat{i})=8+18=26$. 
 Again, $\frac{|\vec{A}|}{|\vec{B}|}=\frac{\sqrt{16+36}}{\sqrt{4+9}} \neq \frac{1}{2}$. 
 Again, $\vec{B}=\frac{1}{2}\vec{A}$ (Parallel, not anti-parallel).

question: A force of (7i + 6k) N makes a body move on a rough plane with a velocity of (3j + 4k) ms^-1. Calculate the power in watt
question_latex: A force of $(7\hat{i}+6\hat{k})$ N makes a body move on a rough plane with a velocity of $(3\hat{j}+4\hat{k})ms^{-1}$. Calculate the power in watt
solution: Power, $P=\vec{F}.\vec{v}=(7\hat{i}+6\hat{k}).(3\hat{j}+4\hat{k}) = (7\times 0) + (0\times 3) + (6\times 4) = 24$ W

question: A particle moves around a circular path of radius 'r' with uniform speed 'V'. After moving half the circle, the average acceleration of the particle is [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: A particle moves around a circular path of radius '$r$' with uniform speed '$V$'. After moving half the circle, the average acceleration of the particle is [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: Average acceleration $= \frac{\text{Change in velocity}}{\text{time}}$. Change in velocity in half revolution $= V - (-V) = 2V$. Time taken $t = \frac{\pi r}{V}$. Average acceleration $= \frac{2V}{\pi r / V} = \frac{2V^2}{\pi r}$.

question: A cyclist goes round a circular path of circumference 34.3 m in sqrt(22) s, the angle made by him with the vertical will be
question_latex: A cyclist goes round a circular path of circumference $34.3$ m in $\sqrt{22}$ s, the angle made by him with the vertical will be
solution: Here, $2\pi r=34.3 \Rightarrow r=\frac{34.3}{2\pi}$. Speed $v=\frac{2\pi r}{T}=\frac{34.3}{\sqrt{22}}$. Angle of banking $\theta=tan^{-1}(\frac{v^2}{rg})=45^{\circ}$.

question: A body is released from the top of a tower 'H' meter high. It takes t second to reach the ground. The height of the body t/2 second after release is [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: A body is released from the top of a tower '$H$' meter high. It takes $t$ second to reach the ground. The height of the body $\frac{t}{2}$ second after release is [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: $u=0 \Rightarrow H = \frac{1}{2}gt^2 \Rightarrow t^2 = \frac{2H}{g}$. Let $h'$ be height fallen in time $t/2$. $h' = \frac{1}{2}g(\frac{t}{2})^2 = \frac{1}{2}g\frac{t^2}{4} = \frac{1}{8}gt^2 = \frac{1}{8}g\cdot\frac{2H}{g} = \frac{H}{4}$. Height from ground $h = H - h' = H - \frac{H}{4} = \frac{3H}{4}$.

question: A string of length 'l' fixed at one end carries a mass 'm' at the other end. The string makes 3/π revolutions/second around the vertical axis through the fixed end as shown in figure. The tension 'T' in the string is [MHT-CET 2020]
question_latex: A string of length '$l$' fixed at one end carries a mass '$m$' at the other end. The string makes $\frac{3}{\pi}$ revolutions/second around the vertical axis through the fixed end as shown in figure. The tension '$T$' in the string is [MHT-CET 2020]
solution: Horizontal component $T\sin\theta = mr\omega^2$. Since $r=l\sin\theta$, $T=m\omega^2 l$. Frequency $f = 3/\pi \Rightarrow \omega = 2\pi f = 2\pi(3/\pi) = 6$. So, $\omega^2 = 36$. Hence, $T = 36 ml$.

question: A vehicle covers a distance 'x' with speed V1 and then same distance 'x' with speed V2 in the same direction. The average speed of the vehicle is [2025]
question_latex: A vehicle covers a distance '$x$' with speed $V_{1}$ and then same distance '$x$' with speed $V_{2}$ in the same direction. The average speed of the vehicle is [2025]
solution: Average speed $= \frac{\text{Total distance}}{\text{Total time}} = \frac{2x}{\frac{x}{V_1} + \frac{x}{V_2}} = \frac{2x}{\frac{x(V_1+V_2)}{V_1 V_2}} = \frac{2V_1 V_2}{V_1 + V_2}$.

question: A particle of mass m moves with constant speed along a circular path of radius r under the action of force F. Its speed is
question_latex: A particle of mass $m$ moves with constant speed along a circular path of radius $r$ under the action of force $F$. Its speed is
solution: $F = \frac{mv^2}{r} \Rightarrow v = \sqrt{\frac{Fr}{m}}$.

question: With what minimum speed a particle be projected from the origin so that it is able to pass through a given point (30 m, 40 m)?
question_latex: With what minimum speed a particle be projected from the origin so that it is able to pass through a given point ($30$ m, $40$ m)?
solution: Using $y=x\tan\theta - \frac{gx^2}{2u^2}(1+\tan^2\theta)$, we find the condition for real $\theta$. Solving $(u^2-400)^2 \geq 200000$ leads to $u \geq 30 ms^{-1}$.

question: Two projectiles A and B are projected with velocities sqrt(2)V and V respectively. They have the same range. If A is thrown at angle of 15° with the horizontal, the angle of projection of B with horizontal will be
question_latex: Two projectiles A and B are projected with velocities $\sqrt{2}V$ and $V$ respectively. They have the same range. If A is thrown at angle of $15^{\circ}$ with the horizontal, the angle of projection of B with horizontal will be
solution: $R_1 = R_2 \Rightarrow \frac{u_1^2 \sin 2\theta_1}{g} = \frac{u_2^2 \sin 2\theta_2}{g} \Rightarrow 2V^2 \sin 30^{\circ} = V^2 \sin 2\theta_2 \Rightarrow \sin 2\theta_2 = 1 \Rightarrow 2\theta_2 = 90^{\circ} \Rightarrow \theta_2 = 45^{\circ}$.

question: A particle performing uniform circular motion of radius pi/2 m makes x revolutions in time t. Its tangential velocity is [2025, 2023, 2022, 2020]
question_latex: A particle performing uniform circular motion of radius $\frac{\pi}{2}$ m makes $x$ revolutions in time $t$. Its tangential velocity is [2025,2023,2022,2020]
solution: Radius $r = \pi/2$ m, frequency $f = x/t$. Tangential velocity $v = \omega r = 2\pi f r = 2\pi \times \frac{x}{t} \times \frac{\pi}{2} = \frac{\pi^2 x}{t}$.

question: A body is moved along a straight line by a machine delivering constant power. The distance moved by the body in time 't' is proportional to [2025, 2014]
question_latex: A body is moved along a straight line by a machine delivering constant power. The distance moved by the body in time '$t$' is proportional to [2025, 2014]
solution: $P = Fv = mav \Rightarrow P = m \frac{dv}{dt} v$. Integrating: $\frac{1}{2}v^2 = \frac{P}{m}t \Rightarrow v \propto t^{1/2}$. Since $v = \frac{ds}{dt}$, integrating again gives $s \propto t^{3/2}$.

question: Two bodies A and B are projected with same velocity. If bodies A and B are projected at an angle of 30° and 60° with the horizontal respectively, the ratio of maximum height reached by the body A to that of body B is [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: Two bodies A and B are projected with same velocity. If bodies A and B are projected at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ and $60^{\circ}$ with the horizontal respectively, the ratio of maximum height reached by the body A to that of body B is [MHT-CET 2021]
solution: $H = \frac{u^2 \sin^2 \theta}{2g}$. Ratio $\frac{H_A}{H_B} = \frac{\sin^2 30^{\circ}}{\sin^2 60^{\circ}} = \frac{(1/2)^2}{(\sqrt{3}/2)^2} = \frac{1/4}{3/4} = \frac{1}{3}$.

question: A stone is projected at angle 'theta' with velocity 'u'. If it executes nearly a circular motion at its maximum point for short time, the radius of the circular path will be [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: A stone is projected at angle '$\theta$' with velocity '$u$'. If it executes nearly a circular motion at its maximum point for short time, the radius of the circular path will be ($g$ = acceleration due to gravity) [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: At max point, $v = u\cos\theta$ and acceleration $a = g$. For circular motion $a = v^2/r \Rightarrow g = \frac{(u\cos\theta)^2}{r} \Rightarrow r = \frac{u^2 \cos^2 \theta}{g}$.

question: A projectile is projected with velocity kve in vertically upward direction from the ground into the space (ve is the escape velocity and k < 1). If air resistance is considered to be negligible then the maximum height from the center of earth to which it can go will be (R = radius of earth)
question_latex: A projectile is projected with velocity $kv_{e}$ in vertically upward direction from the ground into the space ($v_{e}$ is the escape velocity and $k<1$). If air resistance is considered to be negligible then the maximum height from the center of earth to which it can go will be ($R = $ radius of earth)
solution: By conservation of energy: $\frac{1}{2}m(kv_e)^2 = \frac{mgh}{1+h/R}$. Max height from center $r = R+h$. Substituting $v_e = \sqrt{2gR}$ and solving gives $r = \frac{R}{1-k^2}$.

question: A ball of mass (m) 0.5 kg is attached to the end of a string having length (L) 0.5 m. The ball is rotated on a horizontal circular path about vertical axis. The maximum tension that the string can bear is 324 N. The maximum possible value of angular velocity of ball (in rad/s) is
question_latex: A ball of mass ($m$) $0.5$ kg is attached to the end of a string having length ($L$) $0.5$ m. The ball is rotated on a horizontal circular path about vertical axis. The maximum tension that the string can bear is $324$ N. The maximum possible value of angular velocity of ball (in $rad/s$) is
solution: $T\sin\theta = m(L\sin\theta)\omega^2 \Rightarrow T = mL\omega^2$. $\omega = \sqrt{T/mL} = \sqrt{324 / (0.5 \times 0.5)} = \sqrt{324/0.25} = \sqrt{1296} = 36$ rad/s.

question: Two projectiles of same mass have their maximum kinetic energies in the ratio 3:2. The ratio of maximum heights is also 3:2. The ratio of their horizontal ranges is [2025]
question_latex: Two projectiles of same mass have their maximum kinetic energies in the ratio $3:2$. The ratio of maximum heights is also $3:2$. The ratio of their horizontal ranges is [2025]
solution: KE ratio $= u_1^2/u_2^2 = 3/2$. Height ratio $= u_1^2 \sin^2 \theta_1 / (u_2^2 \sin^2 \theta_2) = 3/2$. Since $u_1^2/u_2^2 = 3/2$, it implies $\sin^2 \theta_1 = \sin^2 \theta_2 \Rightarrow \theta_1 = \theta_2$. Range ratio $R_1/R_2 = u_1^2 \sin 2\theta_1 / (u_2^2 \sin 2\theta_2) = u_1^2/u_2^2 = 3/2$.

question: A particle is moving along a circular path with a uniform speed. How does its angular velocity change when it completes half of the circular path?
question_latex: A particle is moving along a circular path with a uniform speed. How does its angular velocity change when it completes half of the circular path?
solution: Uniform speed implies constant $\omega$ (angular velocity), so there is no change.

question: A particle moves in a circle of radius 30cm. Its liner speed is given by v = 2t, where t is in second and v in ms^-1. Find out its radial and tangential acceleration at t = 3s, respectively.
question_latex: A particle moves in a circle of radius $30$ cm. Its liner speed is given by $v=2t,$ where $t$ is in second and $v$ in $ms^{-1}$. Find out its, radial and tangential acceleration at $t=3s$, respectively.

question: A particle of mass = 5 is moving with a uniform speed v = 3sqrt(2) in the XOY plane along the line Y = X + 4. The magnitude of the angular momentum of the particle about the origin is
question_latex: A particle of mass $=5$ is moving with a uniform speed $v=3\sqrt{2}$ in the $XOY$ plane along the line $Y=X+4$ The magnitude of the angular momentum of the particle about the origin is
solution: $Y=X+4$. Distance from origin to line $d = 4/\sqrt{1^2+1^2} = 4/\sqrt{2} = 2\sqrt{2}$. Angular momentum $L = mvd = 5 \times 3\sqrt{2} \times 2\sqrt{2} = 5 \times 3 \times 4 = 60$ units.

question: A vehicle moving with 15 km/hr comes to rest by covering 5 m distance by applying brakes. If the same vehicle moves at 45 km/hr, then by applying brakes, it will come to rest by covering a distance [MHT-CET 2020]
question_latex: A vehicle moving with $15~km/hr$ comes to rest by covering $5$ m distance by applying brakes. If the same vehicle moves at $45~km/hr$, then by applying brakes, it will come to rest by covering a distance [MHT-CET 2020]

question: For an object thrown at 45° to horizontal, the maximum height (H) and horizontal range (R) are related as
question_latex: For an object thrown at $45^{\circ}$ to horizontal, the maximum height ($H$) and horizontal range ($R$) are related as
solution: $R = u^2/g$ for $45^{\circ}$, and $H = u^2 \sin^2 45 / 2g = u^2/4g$. Thus $R = 4H$.

question: For a projectile, the maximum height and horizontal range are same. The angle of projection 'theta' of the projectile is [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: For a projectile, the maximum height and horizontal range are same. The angle of projection '$\theta$' of the projectile is [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: $H=R \Rightarrow \frac{u^2 \sin^2 \theta}{2g} = \frac{2u^2 \sin\theta \cos\theta}{g} \Rightarrow \frac{\sin\theta}{\cos\theta} = 4 \Rightarrow \tan\theta = 4 \Rightarrow \theta = \tan^{-1}(4)$.

question: A fighter plane enters inside the enemy territory, at time t=0 with velocity v0 = 250 ms^-1 and moves horizontally with constant acceleration a = 20 ms^-2. An enemy tank at the border, spot the plane and fire shots at an angle theta = 60° with the horizontal and with velocity u = 600 ms^-1. At what altitude H of the plane it can be hit by the shot?
question_latex: A fighter plane enters inside the enemy territory, at time $t=0$ with velocity $v_{0}=250~ms^{-1}$ and moves horizontally with constant acceleration $a=20ms^{-2}$ (see figure). An enemy tank at the border, spot the plane and fire shots at an angle $\theta=60^{\circ}$ with the horizontal and with velocity $u=600~ms^{-1}$. At what altitude $H$ of the plane it can be hit by the shot?
solution: Horizontal collision: $v_0 t + 0.5 a t^2 = (u\cos\theta)t$. $250 + 10t = 600(0.5) = 300 \Rightarrow 10t = 50 \Rightarrow t=5s$. Altitude $H = (u\sin\theta)t - 0.5 gt^2 = 600(\sqrt{3}/2) \times 5 - 5(25) = 1500\sqrt{3} - 125 \approx 2473$ m. (Note: Solution in pdf text calculated $1500\sqrt{3} - 125 = 2473$, matches D).

question: A wheel completes 2000 revolutions to cover the 9.5 km distance, then the diameter of the wheel is
question_latex: A wheel completes $2000$ revolutions to cover the $9.5$ km distance, then the diameter of the wheel is
solution: Distance $S = n \pi D \Rightarrow 9500 = 2000 \times \pi \times D \Rightarrow D = 9.5 / (2\pi) \approx 1.5$ m.

question: A vehicle runs on a straight road of length 'L'. It travels half the distance with speed V and the remaining distance with speed v/3. Its average speed is [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: A vehicle runs on a straight road of length '$L$' It travels half the distance with speed $V$ and the remaining distance with speed $\frac{v}{3}$ Its average speed is [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: $t_1 = (L/2)/V = L/2V$. $t_2 = (L/2)/(V/3) = 3L/2V$. Total time $T = 4L/2V = 2L/V$. Average speed $= L / (2L/V) = V/2$.

question: For a particle executing uniform circular motion, which one of the following is correct? [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: For a particle executing uniform circular motion, which one of the following is correct? [MHT-CET 2023]
options: A. Direction of acceleration of the particle remains same.
B. Velocity of the particle is parallel to the radius vector.
C. Magnitude of acceleration of particle remains constant.
D. Magnitude of velocity of particle keeps changing as the particle moves.
solution: In UCM, magnitude of centripetal acceleration ($v^2/r$) is constant, but its direction changes.

question: Two balls A and B are projected at an angle of 45° and 60° respectively so that the maximum heights reached are same for both. The ratio of initial velocity of projection of the ball A to that for ball B is [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: Two balls A and B are projected at an angle of $45^{\circ}$ and $60^{\circ}$ respectively so that the maximum heights reached are same for both. The ratio of initial velocity of projection of the ball A to that for ball B is ($sin~45^{\circ}=cos~45^{\circ}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}},sin~60^{\circ}=cos~30^{\circ}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$) [MHT-CET 2022]
solution: $H_A = H_B \Rightarrow u_A^2 \sin^2 45 = u_B^2 \sin^2 60 \Rightarrow u_A^2/u_B^2 = (\sin 60 / \sin 45)^2 = (\frac{\sqrt{3}/2}{1/\sqrt{2}})^2 = (\sqrt{3/2})^2 = 3/2$. So $u_A/u_B = \sqrt{3}:\sqrt{2}$.

question: A particle P is moving in a circle of radius with a uniform speed v. C is the centre of the circle and AB is the diameter. The angular velocity of P about A and C is in ratio
question_latex: A particle P is moving in a circle of radius with a uniform speed $v$. C is the centre of the circle and AB is the diameter. The angular velocity of P about A and C is in ratio
solution: Angular velocity about center $C: \omega_C = v/r$. Angular velocity about point $A$ on circumference: $\omega_A = v/(2r)$. Ratio $\omega_A/\omega_C = 1:2$.

question: The maximum and minimum tension in the string whirling in a circle of radius 2.5 m with constant velocity are in the ratio 5: 3 then its velocity is
question_latex: The maximum and minimum tension in the string whirling in a circle of radius $2.5$ m with constant velocity are in the ratio $5:3$ then its velocity is
solution: $T_{max}/T_{min} = (v^2/rg + 1)/(v^2/rg - 1) = 5/3 \Rightarrow 3v^2/rg + 3 = 5v^2/rg - 5 \Rightarrow 2v^2/rg = 8 \Rightarrow v^2 = 4rg = 4 \times 9.8 \times 2.5 = 98$. $v = \sqrt{98} ms^{-1}$.

question: The angle of projection of a projectile for which the horizontal range and maximum height are equal is
question_latex: The angle of projection of a projectile for which the horizontal range and maximum height are equal is
solution: Identical to Q23. $\tan\theta = 4H/R$. If $H=R$, $\tan\theta=4$.

question: A stone thrown at an angle theta to the horizontal a projectile makes an angle pi/4 with the horizontal, then its initial velocity and angle of projection are, respectively
question_latex: A stone thrown at an angle $\theta$ to the horizontal a projectile makes an angle $\pi/4$ with the horizontal, then its initial velocity and angle of projection are, respectively
solution: Here, $h = u^2 \sin^2 \theta / 2g \Rightarrow u \sin\theta / g = \sqrt{2h/g}$. Time of flight $T = 2u \sin\theta / g = 2\sqrt{2h/g}$. (Question phrasing seems to ask for Time of Flight based on the solution provided).

question: A body throws a ball in air at an angle of 60° to the horizontal along a road with a speed of 10 m/s. Another boy sitting in a nearby moving car observes the ball. The car is moving at a uniform speed of 5 m/s. The boy in the car will find the ball is moving (cos 60° = 1/2) [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: A body throws a ball in air at an angle of $60^{\circ}$ to the horizontal along a road with a speed of $10~m/s$. Another boy sitting in a nearby moving car observes the ball. The car is moving at a uniform speed of $5~m/s$. The boy in the car will find the ball is moving ($cos~60^{\circ}=\frac{1}{2}$) [MHT-CET 2024]
options: A. along a horizontal straight line
B. along a straight line inclined at an angle of 60° with the horizontal.
C. along a vertical straight line
solution: $u_x = 10\cos 60^{\circ} = 5$ m/s. Speed of car $= 5$ m/s. Since car and ball have same horizontal speed, relative horizontal velocity is zero. Only vertical motion is observed.

question: Given P . Q = 0, then |P x Q| is
question_latex: Given $\vec{P}\cdot\vec{Q}=0$, then $|\vec{P}\times\vec{Q}|is$
solution: $\vec{P}\cdot\vec{Q}=0 \Rightarrow \theta=90^{\circ}$. $|\vec{P}\times\vec{Q}| = PQ \sin 90^{\circ} = PQ$.

question: A can filled with water is revolved in a vertical of radius 4 m and the water does not fall down. The time period for a revaluation is about
question_latex: A can filled with water is revolved in a vertical of radius $4$ m and the water does not fall down. The time period for a revaluation is about
solution: At the top, $mg = mv^2/r$ for critical case $\Rightarrow v = \sqrt{gr}$. Period $T = 2\pi r / v = 2\pi \sqrt{r/g} = 2\pi \sqrt{4/9.8} \approx 4$ s.

question: A mass' m' is tied to one end of a spring and whirled in a horizontal circle with constant angular velocity. The elongation in the spring is 1 cm. If the angular speed is doubled, the elongation in the spring is 6 cm. The original length of the spring is
question_latex: A mass' m' is tied to one end of a spring and whirled in a horizontal circle with constant angular velocity. The elongation in the spring is $1$ cm. If the angular speed is doubled, the elongation in the spring is $6$ cm. The original length of the spring is
solution: $m(l+1)\omega^2 = k(1)$ and $m(l+6)(2\omega)^2 = k(6)$. Dividing: $\frac{l+1}{4(l+6)} = 1/6 \Rightarrow 6l+6 = 4l+24 \Rightarrow 2l=18 \Rightarrow l=9$ cm.

question: The equation of the trajectory of a ball projected at an angle 'theta' with the horizontal, is given as y = sqrt(3)x - gx^2 / 2. The initial velocity of the ball is [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: The equation of the trajectory of a ball projected at an angle '$\theta$' with the horizontal, is given as $y=\sqrt{3}x-\frac{gx^{2}}{2}$. The initial velocity of the ball is ($g$ = acceleration due to gravity, $sin~30^{\circ}=0.5=cos~60^{\circ}, cos~30^{\circ}=\sqrt{3}/2=sin~60^{\circ}$) [MHT-CET 2022]
solution: Compare with $y = x\tan\theta - \frac{g x^2}{2 u^2 \cos^2 \theta}$. $\tan\theta = \sqrt{3} \Rightarrow \theta=60^{\circ}$. $u^2 \cos^2 60 = 1 \Rightarrow u^2 (1/4) = 1 \Rightarrow u=2$ m/s.

question: The ratio of the angular speed of the hour hand of a clock to that of its minute hand is [MHT-CET 2019]
question_latex: The ratio of the angular speed of the hour hand of a clock to that of its minute hand is [MHT-CET 2019]
solution: Hour hand period $T_h = 12$ hrs. Minute hand period $T_m = 1$ hr. $\omega_h/\omega_m = T_m/T_h = 1/12$.

question: A body starts falling from height'h' and travels a distance h/2 during last second of its motion then time of flight in second is [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: A body starts falling from height '$h$' and travels a distance $h/2$ during last second of its motion then time of flight in second is [MHT-CET 2021]
solution: $h = 0.5 gt^2$. In last second, distance $= h/2 \Rightarrow h/2 = 0.5 g(t-1)^2$. Ratio: $2 = t^2 / (t-1)^2 \Rightarrow \sqrt{2} = t/(t-1) \Rightarrow \sqrt{2}t - \sqrt{2} = t \Rightarrow t = \frac{\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{2}-1} = 2 + \sqrt{2}$.

question: When the bob of mass 'm' moves in a horizontal circle of radius with uniform speed 'v' having length of string 'L' describes a cone of semi vertical angle 'theta'. The centripetal force acting on the bob is given by [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: When the bob of mass '$m$' moves in a horizontal circle of radius with uniform speed '$v$' having length of string '$L$' describes a cone of semi vertical angle '$\theta$'. The centripetal force acting on the bob is given by ($g$ = acceleration due to gravity) [MHT-CET 2022]
solution: $F = T\sin\theta$, $mg = T\cos\theta \Rightarrow F = mg\tan\theta$. In triangle, $\tan\theta = r / \sqrt{L^2 - r^2}$. So $F = mgr / \sqrt{L^2 - r^2}$.

question: Two boys are standing at points A and B on the ground, where distance AB = x. The boy at B starts running perpendicular to AB with velocity v1. The boy at A starts running simultaneously with velocity v and meets the other boy in time t. The value of t is [2025]
question_latex: Two boys are standing at points A and B on the ground, where distance $AB=x$. The boy at B starts running perpendicular to AB with velocity $v_{1}$. The boy at A starts running simultaneously with velocity $v$ and meets the other boy in time $t$. The value of $t$ is [2025]
solution: Distance $d_1 = vt$, $d_2 = v_1 t$. By Pythagoras: $(vt)^2 = x^2 + (v_1 t)^2 \Rightarrow t^2 (v^2 - v_1^2) = x^2 \Rightarrow t = [x^2 / (v^2 - v_1^2)]^{1/2}$.

question: Two bullets are fired simultaneously, horizontally and with different speeds from the same place. Which bullet will hit the ground first?
question_latex: Two bullets are fired simultaneously, horizontally and with different speeds from the same place. Which bullet will hit the ground first?
solution: Vertical motion is independent of horizontal speed. Both fall through same height under $g$, so $t = \sqrt{2h/g}$.

question: A particle is performing uniform circular motion. If 'theta', 'omega', 'alpha' and 'a' are its angular displacement, angular velocity, angular acceleration and centripetal acceleration respectively, then which of the following is 'WRONG'? [MHT-CET 2020]
question_latex: A particle is performing uniform circular motion. If '$\theta$', '$\omega$', '$\alpha$' and '$a$' are its angular displacement, angular velocity, angular acceleration and centripetal acceleration respectively, then which of the following is 'WRONG'? [MHT-CET 2020]
solution: In UCM, $\omega$ and $\alpha$ are both axial vectors. In UCM, $\alpha=0$. If non-uniform, $\omega$ and $\alpha$ are parallel/anti-parallel. They are never perpendicular.

question: A particle has velocity sqrt(3rg) at the highest pint in vertical circle. Find the ratio of tensions at the highest and lowest point
question_latex: A particle has velocity $\sqrt{3rg}$ at the highest pint in vertical circle. Find the ratio of tensions at the highest and lowest point
solution: $T_{top} = mv_{top}^2/r - mg = 3mg - mg = 2mg$. By energy conservation, $v_{low}^2 = v_{top}^2 + 4gr = 7gr$. $T_{low} = mv_{low}^2/r + mg = 7mg + mg = 8mg$. Ratio $= 2/8 = 1/4$.

question: A body is projected with velocity at two different angles of projection with respect to horizontal so that the horizontal range (R) is same. It' t1 and ' t2' are the times taken for the two paths, the product (t1 . t2) is [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: A body is projected with velocity at two different angles of projection with respect to horizontal so that the horizontal range ($R$) is same. It' $t_{1}$ and ' $t_{2}$' are the times taken for the two paths, the product ($t_{1}.t_{2}$) is ($g$= acceleration due to gravity) [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: $t_1 = 2u\sin\theta/g$, $t_2 = 2u\cos\theta/g$. $t_1 t_2 = 2 (2u^2 \sin\theta \cos\theta)/g^2 = 2R/g$.

question: A projectile is thrown with initial velocity u0 making an angle of 60° with vertical. If it remains in air for 3 second, the initial velocity u0 was (g=9.8 m/s^2) [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: A projectile is thrown with initial $u_{0}$ making an angle of $60^{\circ}$ with vertical. If it remains in air for $3$ second, the initial velocity $u_{0}$ was ($g=9.8ms^{-2}, sin~30^{\circ}=0.5=cos~60^{\circ}$) [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: Angle with vertical $60^{\circ} \Rightarrow \theta$ with horizontal $= 30^{\circ}$. $T = 2u\sin\theta/g \Rightarrow 3 = 2u(0.5)/9.8 \Rightarrow u = 3 \times 9.8 = 29.4$ m/s.

question: What is the angle between i + j + k and i?
question_latex: What is the angle between $\hat{i}+\hat{j}+\hat{k}$ and $\hat{i}$?
solution: $\cos\theta = \vec{A}\cdot\hat{i} / |A| = 1 / \sqrt{3} \approx 0.577$. $\theta = 54^{\circ}44'$. None of the given angles match.

question: A particle is performing uniform circular motion in a horizontal plane. The angular acceleration of the particle is directed along [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: A particle is performing uniform circular motion in a horizontal plane. The angular acceleration of the particle is directed along $[MHT-CET~2023]$
options: A. the radius towards the centre
B. the tangent to the circular path
C. the axis of rotation which is perpendicular to the plane of circle
D. the radius away from the centre
solution: Angular quantities ($\omega, \alpha$) are directed along the axis of rotation.

question: The vector which can give unit vector along x-axis with A = 2i - 4j + 7k, B = 7i + 2j - 5k and C = -4i + 7j + 3k is
question_latex: The vector which can give unit vector along x-axis with $\vec{A}=2\hat{i}-4\hat{j}+7\hat{k}$, $\vec{B}=7\hat{i}+2\hat{j}-5\hat{k}:$ and $\vec{C}=-4\hat{i}+7\hat{j}+3\hat{k}$ is
solution: Let the vector be $\vec{X}$. $\vec{A}+\vec{B}+\vec{C}+\vec{X} = \hat{i}$. Sum $= 5\hat{i} + 5\hat{j} + 5\hat{k}$. So $\vec{X} = \hat{i} - (5\hat{i} + 5\hat{j} + 5\hat{k}) = -4\hat{i} - 5\hat{j} - 5\hat{k}$.

question: A particle performing U.C.M. of radius pi/2 m makes 'x' revolutions in time 't'. Its tangential velocity is [MHT-CET 2020]
question_latex: A particle performing U.C.M. of radius $\frac{\pi}{2}$ m makes 'x' revolutions in time't'. Its tangential velocity is [MHT-CET 2020]
solution: Duplicate of Q11. $v = \omega r = (2\pi x/t) (\pi/2) = \pi^2 x / t$.

question: An unbanked curve has a radius of 60 m. The maximum speed at which the car make a turn is (Take mu = 0.75)
question_latex: An unbanked curve has a radius of $60$ m. The maximum speed at which the car make a turn is (Take $\mu=0.75$)
solution: $v = \sqrt{\mu rg} = \sqrt{0.75 \times 60 \times 10} = \sqrt{450} \approx 21.2 ms^{-1}$.

question: A large number of bullets are fired in all direction with same speed 'u'. The maximum area on the ground on which the bullets will spread is [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: A large number of bullets are fired in all direction with same speed '$u$'. The maximum area on the ground on which the bullets will spread is [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: $R_{max} = u^2/g$. Area $= \pi R_{max}^2 = \pi u^4 / g^2$.

question: A particle performing uniform circular motion of radius pi/2 m makes 'x' revolutions in time 't'. Its tangential velocity is [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: A particle performing uniform circular motion of radius $\frac{\pi}{2}m$ makes 'x' revolutions in time't'. Its tangential velocity is [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: Triplicate of Q11/Q50. $v = \pi^2 x / t$.

question: A car is circulating on the path of radius r and at any time its velocity is v and rate of increases of velocity is a. The resultant acceleration of the car will be
question_latex: A car is circulating on the path of radius $r$ and at any time its velocity is $v$ and rate of increases of velocity is $a$. The resultant acceleration of the car will be

question: Select the correct statement. [2025]
question_latex: Select the correct statement. [2025]
options: A. The product of pressure and volume of an ideal gas will be equal to translational kinetic energy of the molecules.
B. The product of pressure and volume of an ideal gas will be equal to half the translational kinetic energy.
C. The temperature of gas is -100°C. When the gas is heated to +627°C, the r.m.s. speed of the molecules is four times.
D. The temperature of gas is -73°C When the gas is heated to 527°C, the r.m.s. speed of the molecules is doubled.
solution: $K.E. = 1.5 PV$. $v_{rms} \propto \sqrt{T}$. For D: $T_1 = 200 K, T_2 = 800 K$. $v_2/v_1 = \sqrt{800/200} = 2$. Statement D is correct.

question: The linear speed of a particle at the equator of the earth due to its spin motion is 'v'. The linear speed of the particle at latitude 30° is [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: The linear speed of a particle at the equator of the earth due to its spin motion is '$v'.$ The linear speed of the particle at latitude $30^{\circ}$ is [$sin~30^{\circ}=cos~60^{\circ}=1/2, cos~30^{\circ}=sin~60^{\circ}=\sqrt{3}/2$] [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: $v' = \omega (R \cos\theta) = v \cos\theta$. For $\theta=30^{\circ}$, $v' = v \cos 30^{\circ} = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}v$.

question: A particle of mass m is projected with a velocity making an angle of 45° with the horizontal. The magnitude of angular momentum of projectile about the point of projection when the particle is at its maximum height h is
question_latex: A particle of mass $m$ is projected with a velocity making an angle of $45^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. The magnitude of angular momentum of projectile about the point of projection when the particle is at its maximum height $h$ is
solution: $L = m(\vec{r} \times \vec{v})$. At max height, $v = u \cos 45^{\circ}$ and perpendicular distance is $h$. $L = m(u \cos 45^{\circ})h = muh / \sqrt{2}$. (Assuming $v$ in options refers to initial $u$).

question: Neglecting the air resistance, the time of flight of a projectile is determined by
question_latex: Neglecting the air resistance, the time of flight of a projectile is determined by
solution: $T = 2u \sin\theta / g = 2 u_y / g$. It is determined by the vertical component of velocity.

question: In a two dimensional motion of a particle, the particle moves from point A, position vector r1. If the magnitudes of these vectors are respectively, r1 = 3 and r2 = 4 and the angles they make with the x-axis are theta1 = 75° and theta2 = 15°, respectively, then find the magnitude of the displacement vector
question_latex: In a two dimensional motion of a particle, the particle moves from point A to B. If the magnitudes of position vectors are $r_{1}=3$ and $r_{2}=4$ and the angles they make with the x-axis are $\theta_{1}=75^{\circ}$ and $\theta_{2}=15^{\circ}$, respectively, then find the magnitude of the displacement vector
solution: Angle between vectors $\theta = 75 - 15 = 60^{\circ}$. $AB = \sqrt{r_1^2 + r_2^2 - 2r_1 r_2 \cos 60} = \sqrt{9 + 16 - 2(3)(4)(0.5)} = \sqrt{25 - 12} = \sqrt{13}$.

question: The angular displacement of body performing circular motion is given by theta = 5 sin(pi t / 6). The angular velocity of the body at t = 3 second will be [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: The angular displacement of body performing circular motion is given by $\theta=5~sin\frac{\pi t}{6}$ The angular velocity of the body at $t=3$ second will be $[sin\frac{\pi}{2}=1,cos\frac{\pi}{2}=0][MHT-CET~2021]$
solution: $\omega = d\theta/dt = 5(\pi/6) \cos(\pi t / 6)$. At $t=3$, $\omega = 5\pi/6 \cos(\pi/2) = 0$.

question: A frictionless track ABCDE ends in a circular loop of radius R, figure. A body slides down the track from point A which is at a height h=5 cm. Maximum value of R for the body to successfully complete the loop is
question_latex: A frictionless track ABCDE ends in a circular loop of radius R, figure. A body slides down the track from point A which is at a height $h=5$ cm. Maximum value of R for the body to successfully complete the loop is
solution: To complete loop, $h \geq 2.5 R \Rightarrow R \leq h/2.5 = 5/2.5 = 2$ cm.

question: A particle is projected from the ground at an angle of 60° with horizontal with speed u = 20 ms^-1. The radius of curvature of the path of the particle, when its velocity makes an angle of 30° with horizontal is (g = 10 ms^-2)
question_latex: A particle is projected from the ground at an angle of $60^{\circ}$ with horizontal with speed $u=20~ms^{-1}$ . The radius of curvature of the path of the particle, when its velocity makes an angle of $30^{\circ}$ with horizontal is ($g=10~ms^{-2}$)
solution: $v\cos 30 = u\cos 60 \Rightarrow v = 20(1/2) / (\sqrt{3}/2) = 20/\sqrt{3}$. Normal acceleration $g\cos 30 = v^2/r \Rightarrow 10(\sqrt{3}/2) = (400/3)/r \Rightarrow 5\sqrt{3} = 400/3r \Rightarrow r = 400/(15\sqrt{3}) \approx 15.4$ m.

question: The angular speed of the minute hand of a clock in degrees per second is [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: The angular speed of the minute hand of a clock in degrees per second is [MHT-CET 2021]

question: A small particle of mass m is projected at an angle with the x-axis with an initial velocity Vo in the x - y plane as shown in the figure. At a time t < V0 sin(theta) / g, the angular momentum of the particle is
question_latex: A small particle of mass $m$ is projected at an angle with the x-axis with an initial velocity $V_{0}$ in the x - y plane as shown in the figure. At a time $t<\frac{v_{0}sin~\theta}{g},$ the angular momentum of the particle is
options: B. mg V0 t cos(theta) k
C. -0.5 mg V0 t^2 cos(theta) k
D. 0.5 mg V0 t^2 cos(theta) i
solution: $\vec{L} = \vec{r} \times m\vec{v}$. Only force is gravity. Torque $\vec{\tau} = \vec{r} \times \vec{F} = (x\hat{i} + y\hat{j}) \times (-mg\hat{j}) = -mgx\hat{k} = -mg(v_0 \cos\theta t)\hat{k}$. Since $\vec{L} = \int \vec{\tau} dt$, we get $\vec{L} = -0.5 mg v_0 t^2 \cos\theta \hat{k}$.

question: If KE of the particle of mass m performing UCM in a circle of radius r is E. Find the acceleration of the particale
question_latex: If $KE$ of the particle of mass $m$ performing $UCM$ in a circle of radius $r$ is $E$. Find the acceleration of the particale
solution: $E = 0.5 mv^2 \Rightarrow v^2 = 2E/m$. Acceleration $a = v^2/r = 2E/mr$.

question: A car is moving in a circular horizontal track of radius 10m with a constant speed of 10 ms^-1. The angle made by the rod with track is
question_latex: A car is moving in a circular horizontal track of radius $10$m with a constant speed of $10~ms^{-1}$. The angle made by the rod with track is
solution: $\tan\theta = v^2/rg = 100 / (10 \times 10) = 1 \Rightarrow \theta = 45^{\circ}$.

question: Figure shows four position-time graphs for the motion of a body. The body is moving with non-uniform velocity is represented correctly by s-t graph [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: Figure shows four position-time graphs for the motion of a body. The body is moving with non-uniform velocity is represented correctly by s-t graph [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: Non-uniform velocity means the graph is not a straight line. (L) is a curve, indicating changing velocity.

question: A stone tied to one end of rope and rotated in a circular motion. If the string suddenly breaks, then the stone travels
question_latex: A stone tied to one end of rope and rotated in a circular motion. If the string suddenly breaks, then the stone travels
options: B. in direction of centrifugal force
solution: Due to inertia of motion, the object continues in the direction of its instantaneous velocity, which is tangential.

question: A stone is projected vertically upwards with velocity 'V'. Another stone of same mass is projected at an angle of 60° with the vertical with the same speed (V). The ratio of their potential energies at the highest points of their journey, is [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: A stone is projected vertically upwards with velocity 'V'. Another stone of same mass is projected at an angle of $60^{\circ}$ with the vertical with the same speed (V). The ratio of their potential energies at the highest points of their journey, is $[sin~30^{\circ}=cos~60^{\circ}=0.5$, $cos~30^{\circ}=sin~60^{\circ}=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}][MHT-CET 2021]$
solution: PE $\propto H_{max}$. $H_1 = V^2 / 2g$ (for $\theta=90^{\circ}$). $H_2 = V^2 \sin^2 30 / 2g = V^2 / 8g$ (for $60^{\circ}$ with vertical). Ratio $= 4:1$.

question: A body of mass 1 kg is moving in a vertical circular path of radius 1 m. The difference between the kinetic energies at its highest and lowest point is
question_latex: A body of mass $1$ kg is moving in a vertical circular path of radius $1$ m. The difference between the kinetic energies at its highest and lowest point is
solution: $\Delta KE = \Delta PE = mg(2r) = 1 \times 10 \times 2 = 20$ J.

question: The resultant of two vectors A and B is perpendicular to the vector A and its magnitude is equal to half of the magnitude of vector B. Then the angle between A and B is
question_latex: The resultant of two vectors $\vec{A}$ and $\vec{B}$ is perpendicular to the vector $\vec{A}$ and its magnitude is equal to half of the magnitude of vector $\vec{B}$ Then the angle between $\vec{A}$ and $\vec{B}$ is
solution: $B\sin\alpha = B/2 \Rightarrow \alpha=30^{\circ}$ (angle with perpendicular). Angle between $A$ and $B = 90 + 60$ or similar. Calculation: $A+B\cos\theta=0 \Rightarrow \cos\theta = -A/B$. $R^2 = B^2/4 = A^2+B^2-2A^2 = B^2-A^2 \Rightarrow A/B = \sqrt{3}/2$. $\cos\theta = -\sqrt{3}/2 \Rightarrow \theta = 150^{\circ}$.

question: A particle is performing a uniform circular motion along the circumference of a circle of radius 'R' and 'T' is the periodic time. In the time 'T/4' its displacement and distance covered are respectively [MHT-CET 2019]
question_latex: A particle is performing a uniform circular motion along the circumference of a circle of radius '$R$' and '$T$' is the periodic time. In the time '$T/4$' its displacement and distance covered are respectively [MHT-CET 2019]
solution: Displacement is chord length for $90^{\circ} = \sqrt{R^2+R^2} = \sqrt{2}R$. Distance is arc length $= 2\pi R / 4 = \pi R / 2$.

question: A string of length 'l' fixed at one end, carries a mass 'm' at the other end. If the string makes 2/pi revolutions per second around the vertical axis through the fixed end, the tension in the string is [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: A string of length '$l$' fixed at one end, carries a mass '$m$' at the other end. If the string makes $\frac{2}{\pi}$ revolutions per second around the vertical axis through the fixed end, the tension in the string is [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: Duplicate concept of Q6. $T = m\omega^2 l$. $\omega = 2\pi(2/\pi) = 4$. $T = m(16)l = 16 ml$.

question: The velocity time graph of a body moving in a straight line is shown in figure. The ratio of displacement to distance travelled by the body in time 0 to 8 s is [2025]
question_latex: The velocity time graph of a body moving in a straight line is shown in figure. The ratio of displacement to distance travelled by the body in time $0$ to $8$ s is [2025]
solution: Displacement $= \text{Net Area} = 6 - 2 + 4 - 2 + 4 = 10$. Distance $= \text{Total Area} = 6 + 2 + 4 + 2 + 4 = 18$. Ratio $= 10/18 = 5/9$.

question: Which one of the following four statements is false? [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: Which one of the following four statements is false? [MHT-CET 2024]
options: A. The direction of the velocity of a body can change when its acceleration is constant.
B. A body can have a constant velocity and still have a varing speed.
C. A body can have zero velocity still be accelerated.
D. A body can have constant speed and still have a varing velocity.
solution: Constant velocity implies constant magnitude (speed) and direction. Speed cannot vary if velocity is constant.

question: If the resultant of A and B makes angle alpha with A and beta with B then
question_latex: If the resultant of $\vec{A}$ and $\vec{B}$ makes angle $\alpha$ with $\vec{A}$ and $\beta$ with $\vec{B}$ then
options: B. alpha < beta, if A < B
C. alpha < beta, if A > B
D. alpha < beta if A = B
solution: The resultant is closer to the larger vector. If $A > B$, the resultant is closer to $A$, so $\alpha < \beta$.

question: The position 'x' of a particle varies with a time as x = at^2 - bt^3 where 'a' and 'b' are constants. The acceleration of the particle will be zero at time 't' is equal to [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: The position 'x' of a particle varies with a time as $x=at^{2}-bt^{3}$ where 'a' and 'b' are constants. The acceleration of the particle will be zero at time 't' is equal to [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: $v = 2at - 3bt^2 \Rightarrow a = 2a - 6bt = 0 \Rightarrow t = 2a/6b = a/3b$.

question: The horizontal range of a projectile is 4sqrt(3) times its maximum height. Its angle of projection will be
question_latex: The horizontal range of a projectile is $4\sqrt{3}$ times its maximum height. Its angle of projection will be
solution: $\tan\theta = 4H/R = 4H / (4\sqrt{3}H) = 1/\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow \theta = 30^{\circ}$.

question: A cyclist is travelling on a circular section of highway of radius 2500 ft at the speed of 60 mile h^-1. The cyclist suddenly applies the brakes causing the bicycle to slown sown at constant rate. Knowing that after 8 s the speed has been reduced to 45 mile h^-1. The acceleration of the bicycle immediately after the brakes have been applied is
question_latex: A cyclist is travelling on a circular section of highway of radius $2500$ ft at the speed of $60~mileh^{-1}$. The cyclist suddenly applies the brakes causing the bicycle to slown sown at constant rate. Knowing that after $8$ s the speed has been reduced to $45~mileh^{-1}$ The acceleration of the bicycle immediately after the brakes have been applied is

question: A stone is thrown at an angle theta to the horizontal reaches a maximum heights H. then the time of flight of stone will be
question_latex: A stone is thrown at an angle $\theta$ to the horizontal reaches a maximum heights $H$. then the time of flight of stone will be
solution: $H = u^2 \sin^2 \theta / 2g \Rightarrow u \sin\theta = \sqrt{2gH}$. $T = 2u \sin\theta / g = 2\sqrt{2gH}/g = 2\sqrt{2H/g}$.

question: A particle moves along the parabolic path y = ax^2 in such a way that the x-component of the velocity remains constant, say c. The acceleration of the particle is
question_latex: A particle moves along the parabolic path $y=ax^{2}$ in such a way that the x-component of the velocity remains constant, say c. The acceleration of the particle is
solution: $x = ct \Rightarrow y = a(ct)^2 = ac^2 t^2$. $v_y = dy/dt = 2ac^2 t$. $a_y = dv_y/dt = 2ac^2$. Since $v_x$ is constant, $a_x = 0$. $\vec{a} = 2ac^2 \hat{j}$.

question: A string of length 'l' is fixed at one end and carries a mass' m' at the other end. The mass is revolving along a horizontal circle of radius 'r' making 'theta' as the semi-vertical angle of cone and (1/pi) revolutions per second around the vertical axis through fixed end. The tension in the string is [MHT-CET 2020]
question_latex: A string of length '$l$' is fixed at one end and carries a mass' $m$' at the other end. The mass is revolving along a horizontal circle of radius '$r$' making '$\theta$' as the semi-vertical angle of cone and $(\frac{1}{\pi})$ revolutions per second around the vertical axis through fixed end. The tension in the string is [MHT-CET 2020]
solution: $f = 1/\pi \Rightarrow \omega = 2$. $T = m\omega^2 l = m(4)l = 4 ml$.

question: Two particles having mass 'M' and 'm' are moving in a circular path with radius 'R' and 'r' respectively. The time period for both the particles is same. The ratio of angular velocity of the first particle to the second particle will be [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: Two particles having mass 'M' and 'm' are moving in a circular path with radius 'R' and 'r' respectively. The time period for both the particles is same. The ratio of angular velocity of the first particle to the second particle will be [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: $\omega = 2\pi/T$. If $T$ is same, $\omega$ is same. Ratio $1:1$.

question: A small block is shot into each of the four tracks as shown below. Each of the frictionless track rises to the same height. The speed, which the block enters the tracks, is same in all cases. At the highest point of the track, normal reaction is maximum in
question_latex: A small block is shot into each of the four tracks as shown below. Each of the frictionless track rises to the same height. The speed, which the block enters the tracks, is same in all cases. At the highest point of the track, normal reaction is maximum in
solution: $N = mv^2/R - mg$. $N$ is max when $R$ (radius of curvature) is min. (a) has smallest radius.

question: A vehicle is moving on a frictionless horizontal road with velocity 'u' can be stopped in a distance 'd'. Now 40% of its weight is added. If the retardation remains the same, the stopping distance at velocity 'u' is [2025, 2022]
question_latex: A vehicle is moving on a frictionless horizontal road with velocity '$u$' can be stopped in a distance '$d$'. Now $40\%$ of its weight is added. If the retardation remains the same, the stopping distance at velocity '$u$' is [2025, 2022]
solution: $u^2 = 2ad$. If force $F$ stays same, $a' = F/1.4m = a/1.4$. $d' = u^2/2a' = 1.4 d$. (Assuming retardation in question meant retarding force).

question: Two particles are projected simultaneously in the same vertical plane, from the same point, both with different speeds and at different angles with horizontal. The path followed by one, as seed by the other, is
question_latex: Two particles are projected simultaneously in the same vertical plane, from the same point, both with different speeds and at different angles with horizontal. The path followed by one, as seed by the other, is
options: D. A straight line making a constant angle (not 90°) with the horizontal
solution: Relative acceleration is zero ($g-g=0$). Relative velocity is constant. Path is a straight line.

question: The equation of trajectory of a projectile is y = x/sqrt(3) - gx^2/3. The angle of its projection and the horizontal component of velocity are respectively [2025]
question_latex: The equation of trajectory of a projectile is $y=\frac{x}{\sqrt{3}}-\frac{g}{3}x^{2}$ The angle of its projection and the horizontal component of velocity are respectively ($tan~30^{\circ}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}$)[2025]
solution: $\tan\theta = 1/\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow \theta = 30^{\circ}$. $1/(2u^2 \cos^2 \theta) = 1/3 \Rightarrow u^2 (3/4) = 1.5 \Rightarrow u^2 = 2 \Rightarrow u_x = u\cos 30 = \sqrt{2} \times \sqrt{3}/2 = \sqrt{3/2}$.

question: Two cars of 'm1' and 'm2' are moving in the circles of radii r1 and r2 respectively. Their angular speed 'w1' and 'w2' are such that they both complete one revolution in the same time 't'. The ratio of linear speed of m1 to the linear speed of m2 is [MHT-CET 2020]
question_latex: Two cars of '$m_{1}$', and '$m_{2}$' are moving in the circles of radii $r_{1}$ and $r_{2}$ respectively. Their angular speed '$\omega_{1}$' and '$\omega_{2}$' are such that they both complete one revolution in the same time 't'. The ratio of linear speed of $m_{1}$ to the linear speed of $m_{2}$ is [MHT-CET 2020]
solution: $v = \omega r$. If $T$ is same, $\omega$ is same. $v_1/v_2 = r_1/r_2$.

question: Two cars start from a point at the same time in a straight line and their positions are represented by x1(t) = at + bt^2 and x2(t) = Ft - t^2. At what time do the cars have the same velocity? [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: Two cars start from a point at the same time in a straight line and their positions are represented by $x_{1}(t)=at+bt^{2}$ and $x_{2}(t)=Ft-t^{2}.$ At what time do the cars have the same velocity? [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: $v_1 = a + 2bt$, $v_2 = F - 2t$. $a + 2bt = F - 2t \Rightarrow t(2b+2) = F - a \Rightarrow t = (F-a)/(2(b+1))$.

question: A particle is moving in a circle with uniform speed v. In moving from a point to another diametrically opposite point
question_latex: A particle is moving in a circle with uniform speed $v$. In moving from a point to another diametrically opposite point
options: A. the momentum changes by mv
B. the momentum changes by 2 mv
C. the kinetic energy changes by (1/2)mv^2
D. the kinetic energy changes by mv^2
solution: $\Delta \vec{p} = m\vec{v}_2 - m\vec{v}_1 = mv\hat{j} - m(-v\hat{j}) = 2mv\hat{j}$. Magnitude is $2mv$.

question: Two trains, each 30 m long are travelling in opposite directions with velocities 5 m/s and 10 m/s. They will cross after [MHT-CET 2023]
question_latex: Two trains, each $30$ m long are travelling in opposite directions with velocities $5~m/s$ and $10~m/s$. They will cross after [MHT-CET 2023]
solution: Relative speed $= 15$ m/s. Total distance $= 60$ m. $t = 60/15 = 4$ s.

question: A particle 'P' is projected with velocity 'u1' at an angle of 30° with the horizontal. Another particle 'Q' is thrown vertically upward with u2 from a point vertically below the highest point of path of particle 'P'. The necessary condition for the two particles to collide at the highest point is [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: A particle' p' is projected with velocity' $u_{1}$' at an angle of $30^{\circ}$ with the horizontal. Another particle' $Q'$ is thrown vertically upward with $u_{2}$ 'from a point vertically below the highest point of path of particle ' $P'$ The necessary condition for the two particles to collide at the highest point is ($sin~30^{\circ}=0.5$) [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: They collide at peak if $H_1 = H_2$. $(u_1 \sin 30)^2 / 2g = u_2^2 / 2g \Rightarrow u_1/2 = u_2 \Rightarrow u_1 = 2 u_2$.

question: In projectile motion two particles of masses m1 and m2 have velocities v1 and v2 respectively at time t=0. Their velocities become V1' and V2' at time 2t while still moving in air. The value of [(m1 V1' + m2 V2') - (m1 v1 + m2 v2)] is [MHT-CET 2024]
question_latex: In projectile motion two particles of masses $m_{1}$ and $m_{2}$ have velocities, $\vec{v}_{1}$ and $\vec{v}_{2}$ respectively at time $t=0$ Their velocities become $\vec{V}_{1}'$ and $\vec{V}_{2}'$ at time $2t$ while still moving in air. The value of $[(m_{1}\vec{V}_{1}'+m_{2}\vec{V}_{2}')-(m_{1}\vec{v}_{1}+m_{2}\vec{v}_{2})]$ is (g = acceleration due to gravity) [MHT-CET 2024]
solution: $\Delta \vec{P} = \vec{F}_{ext} \Delta t = (m_1+m_2)\vec{g} (2t)$.

question: The angular separation between the minute hand and the hour hand of clock 40 minutes passed after 12 p.m. is [2025]
question_latex: The angular separation between the minute hand and the hour hand of clock $40$ minutes passed after $12$ p.m. is [2025]
solution: Min hand: $40 \times 6 = 240^{\circ}$. Hour hand: $40 \times 0.5 = 20^{\circ}$. Separation $= 240 - 20 = 220^{\circ}$.

question: A particle is performing a uniform circular motion along a circle of radius 'R'. In half the period of revolution, its displacement and distance covered are respectively [MHT-CET 2022]
question_latex: A particle is performing a uniform circular motion along a circle of radius 'R'. In half the period of revolution, its displacement and distance covered are respectively [MHT-CET 2022]
solution: Displacement $= 2R$. Distance $= \text{Half circumference} = \pi R$.

question: A particle is moving in a circle of radius' R' with constant speed 'V'. The magnitude of average acceleration after half revolution is [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: A particle is moving in a circle of radius' $R$' with constant speed '$V$'. The magnitude of average acceleration after half revolution is [MHT-CET 2021]
solution: $\Delta v = 2V$, $t = \pi R / V$. $a_{avg} = 2V / (\pi R / V) = 2V^2 / \pi R$.

question: The speed of revolution of a particle going around a circle is doubled and its angular speed is halved. What happens to the centripetal acceleration?
question_latex: The speed of revolution of a particle going around a circle is doubled and its angular speed is halved. What happens to the centripetal acceleration?
solution: $a = v \omega$. New $a' = (2v) (\omega/2) = v\omega$. Remains unchanged.

question: A projectile is thrown with velocity making an angle with the horizontal. It just crosses the tops of two poles, each of height h, after 1s and 3s respectively. The time of flight of the projectile is
question_latex: A projectile is thrown with velocity making an angle with the horizontal. It just crosses the tops of two poles, each of heighth, after 1s and 3s respectively. The time of flight of the projectile is
solution: $h$ is same for $t_1$ and $t_2$, so $t_1, t_2$ are roots of $h = u_y t - 0.5 gt^2$. Sum of roots $t_1+t_2 = 2u_y/g = T$. $T = 1+3 = 4$ s.

question: What is the unit vector along i + j?
question_latex: What is the unit vector along $\hat{i}+\hat{j}$?
solution: Unit vector $\hat{A} = \vec{A}/|A| = (\hat{i}+\hat{j})/\sqrt{1^2+1^2} = (\hat{i}+\hat{j})/\sqrt{2}$.

question: A body of mass 'm' is tied to one end of a spring and whirled round in a horizontal circle with a constant angular velocity. The elongation in the spring is 1 cm. If the angular velocity is doubled, the elongation in the spring is 5 cm. The original length of the spring is [MHT-CET 2021]
question_latex: A body of mass 'm' is tied to one end of a fa spring and whirled round in a horizontal circle with a constant angular velocity. The elongation in the spring is $1$ cm. If the angular velocity is doubled, the elongation in the spring is $5$ cm. The original length of the spring is [MHT-CET 2021]
solution: $m(L+1)\omega^2 = k(1)$ and $m(L+5)(2\omega)^2 = k(5)$. Dividing: $\frac{L+1}{4(L+5)} = 1/5 \Rightarrow 5L+5 = 4L+20 \Rightarrow L=15$ cm.
